update.description:
This is a TCP server class. I've included some instructions and a description in Server.hh

Let me know if something is not clear, does not work or you have suggestions.

@nima_sh Take a look at the code. Your s-expression parser should implement a `Parse()` method for reading s-expressions from the socket. Let me know if you have any questions.

The coverage is 83% because there's some code difficult to cover. E.g.: When a socket option fails, etc. As far as I know all the code besides these corner cases is exercised in the test.
update.title: TCP server

content.raw:
Hi, this block diagram is great :) I am developing the code of the effector_box in nima_ActionParser branch. The code is using the new server architecture, thus I think it is following the proposed diagram. Currently Some modules of Effector_box  should be improved and also should be tested in different conditions (the new Parser_Test is not ready yet).

Some part of the diagram is not very clear to me: 

1- Which block will update socket_ID in GameState_box, I think it is Server? (line directly from server to gameState)

2- In the update part of the effector_box, we want to have the latest value of effectors or only we want to have effectors values in the current cycle? for each simulation cycle we will have different effectors number. If the answer is the first one we should have updating flag strategy.  

3- I think, in the preceptor code we want to have say and hear protocol? effector_box now is not processing the information of the say effector, I can add it, it is a bit tricky , because , sometimes agents send some invalid character in their say commands that cause crashes in s-expression library. even in the competition, now we have some crash in server because of that :D
content.html:
Hi, this block diagram is great :) I am developing the code of the effector_box in nima_ActionParser branch. The code is using the new server architecture, thus I think it is following the proposed diagram. Currently Some modules of Effector_box should be improved and also should be tested in different conditions (the new Parser_Test is not ready yet).

Some part of the diagram is not very clear to me:

1- Which block will update socket_ID in GameState_box, I think it is Server? (line directly from server to gameState)

2- In the update part of the effector_box, we want to have the latest value of effectors or only we want to have effectors values in the current cycle? for each simulation cycle we will have different effectors number. If the answer is the first one we should have updating flag strategy.

3- I think, in the preceptor code we want to have say and hear protocol? effector_box now is not processing the information of the say effector, I can add it, it is a bit tricky , because , sometimes agents send some invalid character in their say commands that cause crashes in s-expression library. even in the competition, now we have some crash in server because of that :D

Hi Jason, I checked our team's code, you are right, in the beginning of each message we added the length of S-expressions, I will use the following code for testing the parser in the client part of the Parser_test.cc in order to emulate the real agent.

bool send(const string& msg) {

char* out = (char*) msg.c_str();
strcpy(mBuffer + 4, out);
unsigned int len = strlen(out) + 1;
unsigned int netlen = htonl(len);
memcpy(mBuffer, &netlen, 4);
    int ret = write(socketfd, mBuffer, len + 4);
fsync(sock.socketfd);

return ret;

}

Finally map<std::string, double> will be used for parsing the joints command, I will use other structure that has already been developed in "ActionParser" branch to be used in parsing other messages such as Init message and scene Message.

content.raw:
And just one more detail: After the length of the message field, there might be multiple s-expressions, not only one. So, in Jason's original example, 348 is the size in bytes of the message that the agent sends but inside that payload there are several s-expressions.

I'm going to update the server soon.
content.html:
And just one more detail: After the length of the message field, there might be multiple s-expressions, not only one. So, in Jason's original example, 348 is the size in bytes of the message that the agent sends but inside that payload there are several s-expressions.

I'm going to update the server soon.

content.raw:
Hi Nima, 

We took a look at how the agents are sending out messages to the server and it is in the following format:

```
#!c++

x"(...)...(...)"

Here is an actual example:
348"(beam -14.5 0 0)(he1 0.259807)(he2 -2.8381)(lae1 -3.02396)(lae2 0.58819)(lae3 -2.65155)(lae4 -0.56844)(rae1 -3.02396)(rae2 -0.548179)(rae3 2.65155)(rae4 0.56844)(lle1 0)(lle2 0.0481245)(lle3 1.40374)(lle4 -2.43462)(lle5 1.52675)(lle6 0.0722854)(lle7 0)(rle1 0)(rle2 0.0487521)(rle3 1.29475)(rle4 -2.20312)(rle5 1.40424)(rle6 0.0716699)(rle7 0)(syn)"
```

x is the length of all the s-expressions that come after it. So if the s-expressions after it is 348 characters long, then x is equal to 348. Furthermore, x is an unsigned int that is in network endian format. You have to first convert x to unsigned int, then call ntohl(x) to convert it to the proper host endian format. It is important to note that x is not a valid ascii character (it is sizeof(unsigned int) or usually 4 bytes long), but the rest of the message is. 

For the parser, it should have the following public function which the server can call: 

```
#!c++

bool Parser::parse(char* _msg, size_t _len);
```
The server will provide a char array, as well as the number of bytes that is contained in it. Parse() will examine the first sizeof(unsigned int) bytes of _msg, extract x from it, and if _len == x + sizeof(unsigned int), then it should use the s-expression library to parse all the remaining bytes. The Parser class should also have some member data structures to hold the information after they are parsed. For example, there should be a map<std::string, double> that holds the name and velocity information for the hinge joints of the nao. The function returns true when parsing is successful and all the member data structures are filled.
content.html:
Hi Nima,

We took a look at how the agents are sending out messages to the server and it is in the following format:

x"(...)...(...)"

Here is an actual example:
348"(beam -14.5 0 0)(he1 0.259807)(he2 -2.8381)(lae1 -3.02396)(lae2 0.58819)(lae3 -2.65155)(lae4 -0.56844)(rae1 -3.02396)(rae2 -0.548179)(rae3 2.65155)(rae4 0.56844)(lle1 0)(lle2 0.0481245)(lle3 1.40374)(lle4 -2.43462)(lle5 1.52675)(lle6 0.0722854)(lle7 0)(rle1 0)(rle2 0.0487521)(rle3 1.29475)(rle4 -2.20312)(rle5 1.40424)(rle6 0.0716699)(rle7 0)(syn)"

x is the length of all the s-expressions that come after it. So if the s-expressions after it is 348 characters long, then x is equal to 348. Furthermore, x is an unsigned int that is in network endian format. You have to first convert x to unsigned int, then call ntohl(x) to convert it to the proper host endian format. It is important to note that x is not a valid ascii character (it is sizeof(unsigned int) or usually 4 bytes long), but the rest of the message is.

For the parser, it should have the following public function which the server can call: 

bool Parser::parse(char* _msg, size_t _len);

The server will provide a char array, as well as the number of bytes that is contained in it. Parse() will examine the first sizeof(unsigned int) bytes of _msg, extract x from it, and if _len == x + sizeof(unsigned int), then it should use the s-expression library to parse all the remaining bytes. The Parser class should also have some member data structures to hold the information after they are parsed. For example, there should be a map<std::string, double> that holds the name and velocity information for the hinge joints of the nao. The function returns true when parsing is successful and all the member data structures are filled.

content.raw:
The effector messages that a agent sends to the server can be found in the following link: http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Effectors. Each message has different attributes. So I have two ideas for its data structure:

1st idea: Following the current implementation of the parser, we have different data structures for each message types, for example class InitMsg has been implemented for the "init message" (Its attribute are "string rsgName" and "int robotType"). We also have implemented an interface to access its values. 
Some where in simulator we should also handle the situation that the agent can send to messages, even in Simspark, if the agent does not send an effector of the joints, the simulator will execute its previous actions. In current version of the parser, The parser keep its previous state by using singleton call. In this case, if we pass a parse() method to the server class. I think we don't need its return since it will update and keep the parser class state. 

2nd idea: We will consider only the functionality of the parser class, it is simpler and we can use your proposed architecture. we can use map<string , string> for the out-put of the parser method. Here is the example of the input and output of the parser:

S_expression sample: (he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... ( beam 1 0 0)
Out_Put: {("he1", "-10"), ("init_unum", "1"), ( "init_teamname", "FCPOpp"), ("beam_x", "1"), ("beam_y", "2"), ("beam_y", "3")}

Then , we should interpret the results out side of the parser class.

Let me know your opinion or if you have any other idea ? :)
content.html:
The effector messages that a agent sends to the server can be found in the following link: http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Effectors. Each message has different attributes. So I have two ideas for its data structure:

1st idea: Following the current implementation of the parser, we have different data structures for each message types, for example class InitMsg has been implemented for the "init message" (Its attribute are "string rsgName" and "int robotType"). We also have implemented an interface to access its values. Some where in simulator we should also handle the situation that the agent can send to messages, even in Simspark, if the agent does not send an effector of the joints, the simulator will execute its previous actions. In current version of the parser, The parser keep its previous state by using singleton call. In this case, if we pass a parse() method to the server class. I think we don't need its return since it will update and keep the parser class state.

2nd idea: We will consider only the functionality of the parser class, it is simpler and we can use your proposed architecture. we can use map<string , string> for the out-put of the parser method. Here is the example of the input and output of the parser:

S_expression sample: (he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... ( beam 1 0 0) Out_Put: {("he1", "-10"), ("init_unum", "1"), ( "init_teamname", "FCPOpp"), ("beam_x", "1"), ("beam_y", "2"), ("beam_y", "3")}

Then , we should interpret the results out side of the parser class.

Let me know your opinion or if you have any other idea ? :)

content.raw: Is that a single s-expression? I thought that the parentheses need to be balanced. "(he -10)" looks like a finished s-expression to me. @nima_sh , do you have a suggestion for the output of the `Parse()` function?
content.html: Is that a single s-expression? I thought that the parentheses need to be balanced. "(he -10)" looks like a finished s-expression to me. @nima_sh , do you have a suggestion for the output of the Parse() function?

content.raw: This is a sample s-expression message from the agent "(he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... (he2 6.69661)". Here, there are an init message and joints action message. since the order of these messages is not fixed for different teams, I am not sure if the string is a good format for the output of the parser. (if the output of the parser is the information existed in the message e.g. playerNum=1)
content.html: This is a sample s-expression message from the agent "(he1 -10)... (init (unum 1) (teamname FCPOpp))... (he2 6.69661)". Here, there are an init message and joints action message. since the order of these messages is not fixed for different teams, I am not sure if the string is a good format for the output of the parser. (if the output of the parser is the information existed in the message e.g. playerNum=1)

content.raw: `Parse()` has an output parameter with the data in std::string format. The return value will tell you if the string was successfully parsed. The server saves the string in a queue ready to be consumed by the RoboCup3ds plugin.
content.html: Parse() has an output parameter with the data in std::string format. The return value will tell you if the string was successfully parsed. The server saves the string in a queue ready to be consumed by the RoboCup3ds plugin.
